Fake Release Sent to Media
A bogus press release saying that the Applied Physics
Laboratory will "phase out
weapons research" was sent
to various Baltimore media
organizations earlier this
week.
The release was typed on
stationary from the Office of
News and Information, which
does indeed send out press
releases about Hopkins.
The phony document said
that University President
Steven Muller would appoint
a "university and community
committee...to determine how
to phase out weapons research
and to explore socially useful
directions for research."
A statement issued by News
and Information says that
"none of the 'information'
contained in the bogus press
release is factual," and that

quotes attributed to Muller
are "sheer fabrication."
Sue Hartt, director of the
Office of News and Information, said that she has no idea
who sent out the release, and
that she knows of no way of
tracing it. She added that she
does not know how the culprit
acquired the stationary.
Hartt said she first learned
of the release when The Sun
called her Tuesday to inquire
further about the committee.
Since then, she said, several
news outlets have called her.
The News-Letter received a
copy on Tuesday.
Ironically, the same day the
release first appeared Muller,
while speaking in the
freshmen dorms reiterated
that the primary purpose of
the APL is the "defense of the
fleet."

by Timothy McNamara
Admiral Stansfield Turner,
former director of the Central
Intelligence Agency, called for
a "U.S. led, world-wide
crusade against terrorism" in a
speech before a large audience

Turner, who directed the
CIA during the Carter Administration, suggested five
specific measures as a first step
in countering the growing
threat of terrorism to Americans at home and abroad.
He said, "I'm reasonably optimistic that we can reduce the
number of terrorist attacks by
improving U.S. intelligence of
terrorist activities, pressuring
other countries to improve their
surveillance of local terrorist
groups, fortifying American
embassies and installations
overseas, pulling out of particularly dangerous countries
altogether, and not panicking
or overreacting when crises do
arise."

essentially two ways to collect
intelligence: from spies or from
technical devices like satellites
and bugs. Unfortunately, technical devices are not terribly applicable to terrorism since to a
satellite, a truck with a bomb
looks just like a truck without
a bomb.
"Therefore, we have to rely
largely on spies to penetrate terrorist organizations. So improving our network of human
intelligence gathering on terrorist activities should be a
larger concern."

Student Council Gives $1000 to Speaker Series
by Bill Riesen
The student Council pledged
its support Wednesday night to
"The Public Interest in
Science" Symposium, a series
of public lectures to be held in
early spring.
The series, sponsored by the
Hopkins Program in Science
and Writing, part of the
Writing Seminars Department,
and by the Student Council,
will also be supported by the
Humanities Center, and the
Departments of Physics,
Biology, and Earth and
Planetary Sciences.
It will feature noted writers,
scientists, and editors speaking
on topics including, "Women
in Science," "Science and the
Non-Scientist," and "Fraud in
Science."
The series "will be an attempt to bridge the widening
gap between science and the
arts," said Horace Judson,
Henry R. Luce Professor of
Science and Writing in the
Writing Seminars Department.
"The public has a legitimate interest in how science develops
and how it affects public
policy."

The written proposal approved by the Council explains,
"The series title, 'The Public
Interest in Science,' is
deliberately ambiguous, to embrace this full range of topics,
and to allow an emphasis on the
web of relationships that join
science, technology, and the
public, on issues of public
policy, and on the pfesentation
of these by scientists."
The proposal included a list
of possible speakers, but Judson asked that the speakers'
names not be released until arrangements are definite. "We
have to stress that the list is still
very provisional," he said.
Several Council members
said they felt there is a need for
general interest at Hopkins and
that "The Public Interest in
Science" is an important way to
fill that need.
"I think the school needs
more lectureships," said Joff
Masukawa, Chairman of the
Career Advising and Placement
Committee. "If we gave firm
support to this in the beginning,
there's no reason why we
couldn't continue it in later
years."
"I really don't think that

there are enough general interest lectures at Homewood,"
said Council President Jon
Lana. "Certainly the proposed
topics are interesting ones and
are worthy of support. The
thing that's even better is that
several groups are willing to get
together to co-sponsor them.
There should be more of this
cooperation."
"The MSE Symposium has
traditionally been primarily
humanities," noted Council
Vice President Kathie Eubanks,
who worked with Judson to
bring the proposal before the
Council. "The Council has
been thinking of ways to address other areas of the university. This seems to be an ideal
way to do it."
The Council voted unanimously to contribute 1000
dollars to the series from its lectures fund and general fund
and to request a matching
amount from the Student Activities Commission.
Judson said he was pleased
by the Council response. "The
main thing is the affirmation of
support for the idea," he said.
"I am immensely gratified by
the strong response from the

Dr. Victor Corces, a
biochemist in the Department
of Biology at Homewood,
along with three scientists at the

Center, has developed a new
method for the production of
tumor cells that may be useful
in cancer research.

Pellicer, Corces identified and
cloned a mouse gene that, when
mutated by gamma radiation,
appears to be part of a process
which results in tumors in certain tissues. The cloning of this
gene may significantly facilitate
future research in the process
by which tumors develop.
The new method first involves exposing laboratory mice
to gamma radiation. With time,
tumor cells generally develop.
From these, the scientists extract DNA. This DNA is then
introduced into a NIH-3T3 cell.
This is a non-tumorous, healthy
cell that characteristically
reproduces in a single layer.
The altered NIH-3T3 cells, if
tumorous, will not be restricted
to growth in a monolayer.

by Dave Brengel and Mike Silverman
The Hopkins Basketball season officially opens
tomorrow as the hoopsters host Mary Washington.
Last year the Jays narrowly defeated this team 69-67.
This season, Hopkins will be matched solely against
Division III teams, unlike previous years when they
had to face Division I powerhouses such as Virginia,
Maryland, Wake Forest and Virginia Commonwealth.
New opponents are: MIT, Cal Tech, Washington
University, and Washington and Jefferson.
Head Coach Ed "Nappy" Doherty, beginning his
fourth year at Hopkins, is hopeful about the team's
chances to rebound from last season's disappointing
10-13 record. "The players are optimistic and enthusiastic," he said."We have a modest chance of going above the .500 mark this season, with a softer
schedule and good leadership from Puhala. Everybody is out to prove that this is a solid club."
With only one starter among the seven returnees
from last year's varsity squad and no freshman
recruits, the hoopsters may have difficulty maturing
as a team.
Still, Coach Doherty feels that the team has many
strong points. "We have an abundance of 6'2" and
6'3" players and we're much quicker this year than
last," he said. "We'll be out to exploit our advantages
by being more daring on defense. We'll gamble more
because of our quickness, look to the fastbreak outlet
passes and also press more."
The close games will be the critical ones for the Jays
this year if they do hope to finish with a winning
record. Last year, the team was 3-4 in games which
were decided by three or less points. Claims Doherty,
"Discipline wins the close games and we'll run a more
disciplined game plan this year. You have to win the
close ones to make the playoffs."
While hopes are high for the upcoming season, it
would be unfair to expect last year's reserves to quickly
develop into a cohesive starting unit. Doherty admits
that the team "does not have the best talent individually," but believes they will do well "if everybody accepts their role and plays within themselves."
Said the coach, "We're an undetermined commodity, but exploitation of our speed, and our desire to win

by Bill Riesen
The student Council pledged
its support Wednesday night to
"The Public Interest in
Science" Symposium, a series
of public lectures to be held in
early spring.
The series, sponsored by the
Hopkins Program in Science
and Writing, part of the
Writing Seminars Department,
and by the Student Council,
will also be supported by the
Humanities Center, and the
Departments of Physics,
Biology, and Earth and
Planetary Sciences.
It will feature noted writers,
scientists, and editors speaking
on topics including, "Women
in Science," "Science and the
Non-Scientist," and "Fraud in
Science."
The series "will be an attempt to bridge the widening
gap between science and the
arts," said Horace Judson,
Henry R. Luce Professor of
Science and Writing in the
Writing Seminars Department.
"The public has a legitimate interest in how science develops
and how it affects public
policy."

The written proposal approved by the Council explains,
"The series title, 'The Public
Interest in Science,' is
deliberately ambiguous, to embrace this full range of topics,
and to allow an emphasis on the
web of relationships that join
science, technology, and the
public, on issues of public
policy, and on the pfesentation
of these by scientists."
The proposal included a list
of possible speakers, but Judson asked that the speakers'
names not be released until arrangements are definite. "We
have to stress that the list is still
very provisional," he said.
Several Council members
said they felt there is a need for
general interest at Hopkins and
that "The Public Interest in
Science" is an important way to
fill that need.
"I think the school needs
more lectureships," said Joff
Masukawa, Chairman of the
Career Advising and Placement
Committee. "If we gave firm
support to this in the beginning,
there's no reason why we
couldn't continue it in later
years."
"I really don't think that

there are enough general interest lectures at Homewood,"
said Council President Jon
Lana. "Certainly the proposed
topics are interesting ones and
are worthy of support. The
thing that's even better is that
several groups are willing to get
together to co-sponsor them.
There should be more of this
cooperation."
"The MSE Symposium has
traditionally been primarily
humanities," noted Council
Vice President Kathie Eubanks,
who worked with Judson to
bring the proposal before the
Council. "The Council has
been thinking of ways to address other areas of the university. This seems to be an ideal
way to do it."
The Council voted unanimously to contribute 1000
dollars to the series from its lectures fund and general fund
and to request a matching
amount from the Student Activities Commission.
Judson said he was pleased
by the Council response. "The
main thing is the affirmation of
support for the idea," he said.
"I am immensely gratified by
the strong response from the

by Dave Brengel and Mike Silverman
The Hopkins Basketball season officially opens
tomorrow as the hoopsters host Mary Washington.
Last year the Jays narrowly defeated this team 69-67.
This season, Hopkins will be matched solely against
Division III teams, unlike previous years when they
had to face Division I powerhouses such as Virginia,
Maryland, Wake Forest and Virginia Commonwealth.
New opponents are: MIT, Cal Tech, Washington
University, and Washington and Jefferson.
Head Coach Ed "Nappy" Doherty, beginning his
fourth year at Hopkins, is hopeful about the team's
chances to rebound from last season's disappointing
10-13 record. "The players are optimistic and enthusiastic," he said."We have a modest chance of going above the .500 mark this season, with a softer
schedule and good leadership from Puhala. Everybody is out to prove that this is a solid club."
With only one starter among the seven returnees
from last year's varsity squad and no freshman
recruits, the hoopsters may have difficulty maturing
as a team.
Still, Coach Doherty feels that the team has many
strong points. "We have an abundance of 6'2" and
6'3" players and we're much quicker this year than
last," he said. "We'll be out to exploit our advantages
by being more daring on defense. We'll gamble more
because of our quickness, look to the fastbreak outlet
passes and also press more."
The close games will be the critical ones for the Jays
this year if they do hope to finish with a winning
record. Last year, the team was 3-4 in games which
were decided by three or less points. Claims Doherty,
"Discipline wins the close games and we'll run a more
disciplined game plan this year. You have to win the
close ones to make the playoffs."
While hopes are high for the upcoming season, it
would be unfair to expect last year's reserves to quickly
develop into a cohesive starting unit. Doherty admits
that the team "does not have the best talent individually," but believes they will do well "if everybody accepts their role and plays within themselves."
Said the coach, "We're an undetermined commodity, but exploitation of our speed, and our desire to win
and improve on last year will make us more successful.

The Master of Science in Transportation (MST) program provides
graduates with the analytic skills, technological perspective, and
comprehensive understanding of transportation operations needed
to assume professional positions in all facets of the transportation
industry. The MST encompasses three quarters of course work and
a 6-month paid internship in the private or public sector. MST
graduates hold a multitude of jobs with public agencies and
operations and with private transportation and transportationrelated companies.
